related_facts.fact_group_content: Global incidence exceeding 389,000 new cases annually for OSCC.
Incidence of OSCC is estimated to rise 65% by 2050.
The annual incidence of OSCC in 2020 was 377,713 cases worldwide.
By 2040, the incidence of OSCC is predicted to increase by up to 40%.
The highest number of OSCC cases in 2020 was recorded in Asia (248,360).
The number of OSCC cases in Europe in 2020 was 65,279.
The number of OSCC cases in North America in 2020 was 27,469.
The five-year prevalence of OSCC was 959,248.

clusters.title: OSCC Burden
clusters.description: Oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) is a significant global health concern, with over 389,000 new cases annually. The incidence is projected to rise by 65% by 2050, highlighting the growing burden of this disease. In 2020, Asia recorded the highest number of cases, with Europe and North America also reporting substantial figures. The five-year prevalence of OSCC stands at 959,248 cases, indicating a persistent and increasing challenge for healthcare systems worldwide.

related_facts.fact_group_content: 377,713 new cases of lip and oral cavity cancers worldwide in 2020.
177,757 deaths from lip and oral cavity cancers worldwide in 2020.
Mortality rate of close to 50% for lip and oral cavity cancers in 2020.
Increase in OSCC incidence by 2050 is expected to be approximately 147.8% in low HDI countries.
Increase in OSCC incidence by 2050 is expected to be approximately 94.2% in medium HDI countries.
Increase in OSCC incidence by 2050 is expected to be approximately 67.3% in high HDI countries.
Increase in OSCC incidence by 2050 is expected to be approximately 34.3% in very high HDI countries.
10.17% of variability in age-standardized incidence rates attributed to changes in SDIs.
Crude rates of OSCC prevalence range from 1.1 in African populations to 9.9 in populations from Oceania.

clusters.title: Oral Mortality
clusters.description: In 2020, there were 377,713 new cases and 177,757 deaths from lip and oral cavity cancers globally, with a mortality rate nearing 50%. The incidence of oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC) is projected to rise significantly by 2050, particularly in low Human Development Index (HDI) countries, where an increase of approximately 147.8% is expected. Variability in age-standardized incidence rates is partly attributed to changes in Socio-Demographic Indexes (SDIs).

all_merged_facts_in_order.narrative: Looking ahead, OSCC incidence is projected to rise dramatically by 2050, with the most significant increases in low Human Development Index (HDI) countries. Specifically, 147.8% in Low HDI, 94.2% in Medium HDI, 67.3% in High HDI, and 34.3% in Very High HDI countries.
